entry.et: Middle English winnen, from Old English winnan to struggle; akin to Old High German winnan to struggle and probably to Latin venus sexual desire, charm, Sanskrit vanas desire, vanoti he strives for

def.dt: :to get possession of by effort or fortune
:to obtain by work :earn striving to win a living from the sterile soil
:to gain in or as if in battle or contest won the championship
:to be the victor in won the war
:to make friendly or favorable to oneself or to one's cause often used with over won him over with persuasive arguments
:to induce to accept oneself in marriage was unable to win the woman he loved
:to obtain (as ore, coal, or clay) by mining
:to prepare (as a vein or bed) for regular mining
:to gain the victory in a contest :succeed
:to succeed in arriving at a place or a state
:first place at the finish (as of a horse race)
:to survive difficulties and reach a desired or satisfactory end win through to a better life beyond B. F. Reilly
:advantageous or satisfactory to all parties involved a win–win situation a win–win deal
:not likely to give victory, success, or satisfaction :that cannot be won a no–win situation a no–win war
